content.law: 9 George 1 c.22: The Black Act - An act for the more effectual punishing wicked and evil-disposed persons going armed in disguise, and doing injuries and violences to the persons and properties of his Majesty’s subjects, and for the more speedy bringing the offenders to justice.
content.context: In response to a series of raids by two groups of poachers, known as the Blacks

content.law: New York Penal Law § 240.45(4) - Being masked or in any manner disguised by unusual or unnatural attire or facial alteration, loiters, remains or congregates in a public place with other persons so masked or disguised, or knowingly permits or aids persons so masked or disguised to congregate in a public place; except that such conduct is not unlawful when it occurs in connection with a masquerade party or like entertainment if, when such entertainment is held in a city which has promulgated regulations in connection with such affairs, permission is first obtained from the police or other appropriate authorities.
content.context: Tenant farmers used disguises (dressing up like Indians) to attack law enforcement officials, apparently, to provide for public safety after disputes between landlords and tenants.

content.law: A law strictly forbids wearing of any attire that could hide the face of a person. Penalties (fines and imprisonment) are provided for such behaviour. The original purpose of the anti-mask law was to prevent crime or terrorism.
content.context: There are disagreements whether one's religion is a justified cause.

content.law: According to section 17a (2) of the VersammlG, which was adopted by most of the federal states on this point, disguise at meetings is a criminal offense and, according to section 27 (2) and section 29 (2) of the VersammlG, imprisonment of up to one year or punished with a fine. The carrying of masking utensils is punished in the VersG as an administrative offense with a maximum of 511.29 euros. ( § 29 Paragraph 1 No. 1 a VersG)
content.context: The votes of the conservative-liberal coalition under Helmut Kohl in the Bundestag.

content.law: According to § 11, part 5 of the police statute (politiloven) from 1995, it is prohibited to be masked during an event taking place in public. Exempted from the prohibition are participants in theatre, masquerade or similar. In accordance with § 30 of the same law; violation is punishable by a fine or up to three months imprisonment.

The Danish penal code (Straffeloven) § 134 b: Anyone who, in connection with meetings, gatherings, marches or the like in public places, has his or her span class="highlight">face covered in whole or in part with a hood, mask, paint or the like in a manner suitable to span class="highlight">prevent identification, is punished with fine, bond or imprisonment until 6 months.

On demonstrations under § 9 of Versammlungsgesetz: The authority shall prevent people from participating in an assembly if they disguise their face or at least bear items which have the purpose to disguise one’s face. Violation of the ban need not be prosecuted if the mask does not threaten public order and security. Violation of the ban entails, according to § 19a.b of the Law, imprisonment up to six months, repeated offenses one year or a fine.

Ordningslagen: Act (2005: 900) on the prohibition of masking in certain cases: Anyone who takes part in a public gathering, whether or not in accordance with the Ordinance Act (1993: 1617), may not cover the face in whole or in part in a way that makes identification difficult if at the meeting there is a disturbance of the general order or an immediate danger of such a disturbance.

ASSEMBLÉE NATIONALE n° 524 Article 1: No one may, in public space, wear an outfit intended to conceal his face. Exceptions: required or permitted by the laws or regulations, justified by reasons of health or professional reasons, or as part of sports, parties or artistic or traditional events.
content.context: The French Parliament began an initial inquiry on the issue shortly after President Nicolas Sarkozy stated in June 2009 that religious face veils were not welcome within France. Upheld by the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) in 2014.

content.law: A Belgian law adopted in June 2011 prohibits appearing in public "with a face masked or hidden, in whole or in part, in such a way as to be unidentifiable". Violations can result in fines and up to seven days in jail.
content.context: On 11 July 2017 the ban in Belgium was upheld by the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) after having been challenged bytwo Muslim women who claimed their rights had been infringed

content.law: FEDERAL LAW No. 65-FZ OF JUNE 2004: 4. Participants in public events may not: 1) conceal their faces, including through the use of masks, means of disguise or other items specially intended to make them more difficult to identify;

The Preventing Persons from Concealing Their Identity during Riots and Unlawful Assemblies Act (Bill C-309): banning the wearing of masks during a riot or unlawful assembly, carrying a maximum ten-year prison sentence with a conviction of the offence.

LAW OF UKRAINE No.721-VII Article 185: Participation in a meeting, rally, street march, demonstration, other mass event in a mask, helmet, or using other means or methods of masking in order to avoid the identification of the person or the presence of the person ... entail a fine of one hundred fifty to two hundred and fifty tax-free minimum incomes, or an administrative arrest of up to fifteen days.
content.context: Several days after Berkut riot police clashed with Euromaidan protesters, Verkhovna Rada enacted law 721-VII. Became invalid on the basis of Law No. 732-VII of January 28, 2014

content.law: Parliament approved new legislation on 16 May, which stipulates that people who wear clothing that covers their faces, such as burqas, niqabs, full face helmets or scarves (motorcyclists) etc. in places like universities, public transportation or courthouses will face fines of 150 euros (about $167).
content.context: Recent terrorist attacks in France, Belgium, Sweden and elsewhere, and fears that extremists are entering Europe by posing as refugees.

content.law: Act 34,349: Establishing a partial ban on the wearing of face-covering clothing in education, public transport, government buildings and care (Partial Ban on Face-Covering Clothing Act)

Cap. 241K Prohibition on Face Covering Regulation: Anyone who wears a mask at a lawful rally or march, unlawful or unauthorised assembly, or during a riot could be sentenced to up to a year in jail and a fine of HK$25,000.
